IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Incident was recorded. Q-23 is MVR equipped. Body-worn camera is equipped.
Defendant: Herrera, Jose I.
Date of Birth: 09/20/1957
Date of Arrest: 10/02/2023
Time of Arrest: 1556 hours
Maryland License #: H-660-440-325-729
DUI #: 23-231
TRAINING/CERTIFICATES
Trained in administrating Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
Standardized Field Sobriety Test refresher course March 2023.

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)
On 10/02/2023 at approximately 1527 hours I, Trooper Gonzales #7442 currently assigned to the Maryland State Police College Park Barrack was operating marked Maryland State Police vehicle Q-23 in the area of northbound I-495 and MD-295. I was enroute to a call for service of a two-vehicle collision. The call for service was then updated with further information that one of the parties was rolling around in the grass of northbound I-495 and MD-295. I arrived on scene and observed a red Volkswagen Jetta on the right shoulder of northbound I-495 and MD-295 bearing Maryland registration “4EP2446”. Directly in front of the Volkswagen was a white Ford F-150 bearing Maryland registration “6EV9714”.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2)
I observed a Hispanic female and Hispanic Male standing by the Volkswagen as I also observed another Hispanic male lying supine on the grassy area to the right of the right shoulder of northbound I-495 and MD-295. I approached the Hispanic male lying supine on the ground and asked him if he was okay. The Hispanic male advised he was ok and wanted to lie down; I introduced myself to the Hispanic male, spoke to him in Spanish and asked him what occurred. The Hispanic advised he was involved in an accident; I asked the Hispanic male if he needed any medical attention to which he declined. I then asked the Hispanic to stand up in an effort to better communication between us and also asked if he had any identification as well. The Hispanic male laboriously stood up and was observed staggering in place; I asked the Hispanic male to sit down instead to prevent him from falling over and risking injuries. The Hispanic male presented his Maryland driver’s license while he was sitting and was identified as Jose I. Herrera (H/M DOB: 09/20/1957), an MVA check showed his license as valid. I asked for Herrera to remain seated until I’ve returned; during my initial contact with Herrera a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage was emanating from his breath/person. Herrera remained seated as I spoke to the Hispanic Male and Female standing beside the Volkswagen; the driver of the Volkswagen was identified as Daghiana Corredor Rodriguez (H/F DOB: 08/06/1995) and the Hispanic Male was identified as Cesar Ivan Uribe (H/M) who arrived after the collision to check on Corredor Rodriguez. Corredor Rodriguez advised she was exiting the MD-295 ramp to northbound I-495 when she struck the rear of Herrera’s Ford with the front of her Volkswagen. She then advised that when they pulled over to the right shoulder of northbound I-495 and MD-295, she attempted to exchange information with Herrera. Corredor Rodriguez spoke to Herrera who was unaware he was involved in a collision as he then had difficulty balancing as he fell onto the grassy area of the shoulder and was “rolling around” and remained on the ground as seen when I arrived on scene. I returned to speak to Herrera who was still sitting on the grassy area; I asked Herrera if he drank any alcoholic beverages that afternoon as he advised he consumed one (1) Milwaukee beer at approximately 0800 hours coming off of route 100 to northbound I-495. I asked Herrera to stand up to which he needed assistance to get up as I grabbed his right hand and pulled him up to his feet. I directed Herrera to the front left side of Maryland State Police vehicle Q-6; Herrera was observed having slow lethargic movements while moving to Q-6 and also placed his left hand on the hood of Q-6 for stability as well. I spoke to Herrera in Spanish to re-confirm that he drank one (1) Milwaukee beer earlier that morning at approximately 0800 hours to which he affirmed was correct. I spoke to Herrera regarding the details of the collision; as Herrera spoke to me in Spanish, I continued to detect the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath/person. I also observed Herrera leaning on the front left side of Q-6 for stability along with glassy bloodshot eyes since I was able to see him on equal eye level. I asked Herrera if he would undergo standardized field sobriety tests to determine if he was safe to drive to which he agreed.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3)
The evaluation was performed on the right shoulder of northbound I-495 and MD-295. The surface was dry, level, and free of any obvious debris. Herrera appeared to be in good physical health and displayed no visible injuries. It is to be noted that prior to the test while directing Herrera away from the grassy area to the right shoulder of northbound I-495 he was observed having slow lethargic movements. I also had to provide stability to Herrera as he was walking to ensure he didn’t fall.

I asked Herrera the following questions:
Glasses or contacts – yes – prescription glasses for farsightedness; Herrera was wearing glasses at this time and was asked to remove them prior to the first component of testing. Herrera was then allowed to wear his glasses for subsequent components of testing.
Injuries – no – Herrera advised me that his left inner forearm hurt, I asked if he needed EMS for his injury and if it would affect his ability to walk and balance to which he answered “no” to both questions.
Medication – yes – Herrera advises he takes medication for cholesterol.
If he considers himself a healthy person – yes.

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (2/6 clues observed)
The first test was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test, it was explained in Spanish. Herrera was wearing a hat during this component of testing; it was removed to see his eyes better. The tip of a pen was used as the test’s stimulus. It was held approximately 12 - 15 inches away from Herrera’s eyes, slightly above his eye level. Herrera was instructed to look forward, keep his head still, and follow the tip of the stimulus with his eyes and his eyes only. Herrera was positioned in a manner to ensure the headlights of passing traffic would not interfere with the test results. I asked Herrera if he understood the instructions to which he nodded his head up and down in affirmation. Herrera’s pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking. It is to be noted that I had to explain the instructions again to Herrera on four (4) occasions and when I asked him if he understood he nodded his head up and down in affirmation indicating that he did understand. The test also had to be reset six (6) times during the “lack of smooth pursuit” portion of this component due to Herrera not following the instructions even though they have been explained four (4) times and Herrera acknowledged he understood the instructions.

Lack of smooth pursuit – Present in both eyes.
Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation – Nothing to report; this component of testing had concluded due to Herrera’s inability to follow directions.
Onset of Nystagmus prior to 45 Degrees – Nothing to report; this component of testing had concluded due to Herrera’s inability to follow directions.

Walk and Turn (1/8 clues observed)
This test wasn't able to be properly explained and demonstrated due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform this component of testing. He was observed having difficulty maintaining his balance while I tried to explain and demonstrate the instructions in Spanish to him. As such this component of testing has concluded as the next component proceeded.

Herrera was wearing gray tennis shoes.

Instructional Stage:
  • Cannot keep balance (three occasions)
  • Herrera was observed using his right arm against the front bumper guard of the SHA truck for stability while having difficulty keeping his balance.
  • Herrera was also observed swaying in place while trying to keep his balance during this portion of testing.
Walking Stage (1st Nine):
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
Turn
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
Walking Stage (2nd Nine):
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
One Leg Stand (0/4 clues observed)
The test was explained and demonstrated in Spanish. When instructed to start, Herrera was to raise the foot of his choice off of the ground approximately six (6) inches. While his leg was raised, he was to keep his legs straight, watch the raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands and to keep his hands down by his side. I asked Herrera two times if he would be able to perform this component of testing to which he shook his head side to side on two occasions indicating he would not be able to perform this component of testing. As such this component of testing has concluded as the next component proceeded.

Instructional Stage:
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
Seconds 0 – 10:
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
Seconds 11 – 20:
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
Seconds 21 – 30:
  • Nothing to report; this component of testing has concluded due to Herrera advising he would not be able to perform what is required.
While on scene I informed Herrera of his Preliminary Breath Test Rights, Herrera was offered a PBT to which he agreed to. I explained and demonstrated the instructions to Herrera in Spanish.
Herrera was observed leaning against the front bumper guard of the SHA truck for stability during this component of testing.

PBT Result: .24

ARREST
Based on the totality of the circumstances, I had reason to believe Herrera was driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.
  • Involvement in a two-vehicle motor vehicle collision.
  • Driver found lying supine on grassy area during initial contact.
  • Driver having difficulty and exerting considerable effort to stand up.
  • Driver observed staggering in place once he stood up from grassy area.
  • Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from breath/person.
  • Other party of motor vehicle collision stating driver had difficulty balancing, fell onto grassy area, and began rolling around.
  • Driver admitting to consuming one (1) Milwaukee beer at approximately 0800 hours that same day prior to driving.
  • Driver needing assistance in order to stand up from grassy area.
  • Driver having slow lethargic movements when directed to move towards Q-6 and placing his left hand on Q-6 for stability.
  • Driver having glassy bloodshot eyes.
  • Driver having slow lethargic movements when directed to move towards SHA truck and using front bumper guard for stability.
  • Driver needing assistance to ensure he didn’t fall while moving.
  • Driver being unable to fully perform what was required for all components of standardized field sobriety testing. During Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (Driver was unable to follow directions even though he advised he understood when asked on four (4) occasions. During Walk and Turn & One Leg Stand driver advised he would be unable to perform what was asked of him during those components of testing.)
  • Clues during standardized field sobriety testing HGN (2/6), WAT (1/8), OLS (0/4).
  • PBT result of .24.
Due to the number of observations, I concluded Herrera was driving under the influence of alcohol and was unable to operate a vehicle safely.

At approximately 1556 hours I placed Herrera under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol. I immediately notified the barrack and searched his person for weapons and contraband, both with negative results. Herrera was placed in the front passenger seat of my patrol vehicle and was transported to the College Park Barrack per department policy. I checked Herrera’s mouth and observed no foreign objects. Herrera was read his DR-15 Advice of Rights from the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration website in Spanish and provided a copy in Spanish to read along to. At approximately 1631 hours Herrera agreed to take an alcohol concentration test. Herrera received instructions in Spanish during the instructional phase of the alcohol concentration test and submitted two breath samples.

20-MINUTE OBSERVATION PERIOD
I conducted the 20-minute observation period with Herrera upon arriving to the barrack. Herrera was observed from 1556 hours until the time he submitted to the test, and he did not put anything in his mouth. The test was conducted by Sgt. Bishop #6032 of the Maryland State Police on a certified instrument. Herrera had a result of .22 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath at 1652 hours.

Intoximeter Result: .22 BrAC

Herrera was processed and released.

Herrera was issued copies of the following documents:
  • Citations
  • DR-15 Advice of Rights
  • DR-15A Order of Suspension
  • MSP 33
All documents were forwarded to the Prince George’s County, State’s Attorney’s Office.

All events occurred in Prince George’s County, Maryland.

Case closed by arrest.
